abstract: A micro-mechanical technique is used to determine values of the critical stress intensity factor for fracture for grain boundaries of various orientations in Ni alloy 600 exposed to Pressurized Water Reactor (PWR) primary water at 325 °C with a hydrogen partial pressure of 30 kPa. Pentagonal cross-section cantilevers 5 μm wide by 25 μm long were milled using a focused ion beam (FIB) at individual grain boundaries in unoxidised Alloy 600 samples and in samples that had been exposed to simulated PWR environment for 4500 h and for 1500 h. The cantilevers were notched at the grain boundaries using FIB and tested using a nanoindenter to deflect them in bending. The critical stress intensity factor for the fractured cantilevers in samples that had been exposed for 4500 h was measured to be between 0.73 and 1.82 MPa(m)1/2. No intergranular fracture occurred in the samples that had been exposed for 1500 h and in the unoxidised samples. No direct correlation was observed between the grain boundary misorientation angle and the critical stress intensity factor.

author_highlights.sentence: Demonstration of the use of a novel micro-mechanical technique for study of grain boundary embrittlement.
Samples exposed to PWR water conditions for 4500 h experience intergranular fracture, while samples exposed to PWR for 1500 h and unoxidised samples deformed plastically.
The first experimental determinations of the critical stress intensity factor for fracture of individual oxidized grain boundaries of different orientations in Ni alloy 600.

body_text.sentence: The effect of grain boundary microstructure on IGSCC has been widely investigated before [32–34] and it has been concluded that grain boundaries with ∑ > 29 are more susceptible to IGSCC, while the ones with ∑ ≤ 29 increase the resistance of the material to cracking.

body_text.sentence: It was shown that oxidation significantly weakens the grain boundaries; grain boundaries in cantilevers in Alloy 600 exposed to PWR water for 4500 h failed in a brittle matter, but cantilevers milled in both Alloy 600 sample exposed for 1500 h and in the unoxidised specimens yielded, and did not fracture.

body_text.sentence: The current study uses a notched micro-cantilever technique to measure the mechanical properties of individual oxidised grain boundaries of different orientation in Alloy 600 of samples exposed to a PWR environment for different times.
